abstract.p: University of California (Berkeley) economics prof Matthew Rabin receives $500,000 MacArthur Foundation grant for his studies of such phenomena as procrastination and other behaviors that most economists regard as simply irrational; Rabin confesses he often fails to manage his own money efficiently (M)

block.p: Last week, Matthew Rabin, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, received a $500,000 MacArthur Foundation grant for his studies of such phenomena as people's failure to do today what they can put off until tomorrow.

How's that? ''It is partly self-help,'' Professor Rabin, 36, acknowledged. ''I am a severe procrastinator.'' His work involves applying psychological insights about inertia (as in sticking with poor investments), procrastination and so forth to explain behavior that most economists simply regard as irrational.

Last week, Matthew Rabin, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, received a $500,000 MacArthur Foundation grant for his studies of such phenomena as people's failure to do today what they can put off until tomorrow.

How's that? ''It is partly self-help,'' Professor Rabin, 36, acknowledged. ''I am a severe procrastinator.'' His work involves applying psychological insights about inertia (as in sticking with poor investments), procrastination and so forth to explain behavior that most economists simply regard as irrational.
So how is his own self-help plan going? ''It's a complete failure,'' he said, laughing. ''I'm famous for leaving all my money in a checking account,'' earning a quarter-percent interest.

Fellow economists -- ''a very smart, money-savvy group of people'' -- often treat him as a therapist. ''I've gotten a lot of confessions out of them about their failure to manage their money better,'' he said, ''though they almost always blame it on a spouse.''
